relation: NVC has clubs, however, the advertising for them is not well done.

NVC has a cafe and a bookstore that both serve food and snacks. The bookstore has affordable food, however it is mostly snacks and nothing filling. The cafe has sandwiches, soup, paninis, chips, soda, etc., however, most the food is very high priced.
As it is at any other college, you can expect to spend anywhere from an hour and thirty minutes in class to three hours in class with about two hours hours of homework per class.

One major tip is to get to campus about an hour early for class (at least) because parking is a nightmare. As well, apply for the FAFSA and immediately check for eligibility for the BOGS fee waiver, this helped me with finances over the past two years.

Napa Valley College is a fantastic starting school for students who can't afford a 4-year college right away. The teachers are extremely helpful and qualified. NVC is affordable and well worth the two years I have spent here.
pageTitle: Napa Valley College Reviews: Student Reviews and Ratings | Cappex
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {79811=If you want to do your general education, but you don't want to have to pay an arm and a leg, this college is great. In the last two years, I was able to finish my general education at a low cost, under $4000 for tuition and under $1000 for books., 80241=The college offers many clubs and groups to join. They have activities on campus and other opportunities for students to get involved. The theater and music programs also offer entertainment in the form of concert and productions. In April, The Sound of Music will be playing!, 123611=© 2015, Cappex.com, LLC}

textAfterTable: Login to rate or flag the reviews Tiffany from American Canyon, CA 08/16/2011 Reviewer is A current student here. 1 out of 1 people found this review useful. 2 of 30 Categories Comments Great for these types of students Napa Valley College is great for students who haven't decided what they plan on majoring in,for a student that enjoys teachers who are passionate about the subjects they teach, and for students that can not yet afford a four year university and qualify for financial aid. Tips for prospective students Prospective students should immediately speak with a councilor who will help the student determine the classes that are transferable and the courses required for particular degrees. If the student is unsure which course of study to pursue the I recommend taking classes that are transferable and that also fulfill requirements for general education just in case the student decides to pursue a four year university later in the future. Bang for the buck Financially i believe
